Award.AwardTitle: Stochastic Time, Cost and Environmental Impact Optimization of Construction Processes

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to develop a methodology for planning and designing environmentally conscious construction by addressing the interdependency of time, cost and environmental impact (TCEI). The importance of the construction industry in terms of its environmental impact is very well recognized and reflected by the large amount of energy use in existing buildings and construction processes. Nevertheless, the environmental impact of construction processes is still poorly understood. Construction projects are typically executed under multiple constraints such as project schedule, budget, quality and safety. Future advancement of environmentally conscious construction hinges on a better understanding of the interdependency of TCEI.

To achieve the objective, a simulation environment called Simulation of
Environmental Impacts of Construction (SimulEICon) will be developed to quantitatively and accurately ?reveal? the interdependency of TCEI. The researchers will work with facility owners, designers, contractors and subcontractors to collect sample projects, best practices of environmental impact mitigation measures, and other data related to environmental impact analysis. Hypotheses will be tested using SimulEICon and collected data.
The findings of this research are critical for many aspects of construction, for example the selection of optimal construction methods under multiple constraints, e.g., time, cost and environmental impact, the development of new contracting practices that address more stringent environmental requirements, the integration of environmental impact mitigation and project management, and construction education. Since sustainability is a critical education component for many science technology engineering and mathematics (STEM) disciplines, the findings from this project will provide useful data for a wide range of subjects in the construction engineering and management discipline. SimulEICON will also be a valuable teaching and learning tool.

Finally, Florida International University has a proven history of providing STEM education to underrepresented groups. This research will be carefully planned to recruit and retain the brightest women and minority students, so that the project will impact diverse student populations and serve as a cradle for a diverse, high quality construction workforce in the future.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The importance of the construction industry in terms of its environmental impact is very well recognized and reflected by the large amount of energy use in existing buildings and construction processes. Nevertheless, the environmental impact of construction processes is still poorly understood. Construction projects are typically executed under multiple constraints such as project schedule, budget, quality and safety. Future advancement of environmentally conscious construction hinges on a better understanding of the interdependency of construction time, cost and environmental impact (TCEI). Thus, this project was aimed at studying the underlying relationships between building construction time, cost, and environmental impact represented by greenhouse gas emissions as a gauge of several present issues, including energy consumption and global warming.

The researchers started this project by applying a stochastic genetic algorithm to create an analytic process of construction methods under time, cost and environmental impact constraints, and worked with the Florida Department of Transportation for collecting case studies to validate the analytic process. Through two resurfacing projects, a decision-making system based on analytic network process (ANP) and system dynamics has been developed to analyze the changes of project conditions on the relationship of TCEI. Seven typical project conditions, including unavailability of resources, delay in resource delivery, increase in unit cost of resources, unexpected conditions, change in design, adverse financial issues of owner and adverse market conditions, have been considered. The resulting correlation coefficients have suggested positive correlation between the three objectives, TCEI. However, the strength of correlation between objectives is different. Time and cost has a strong correlation, while cost and GHG has a moderately strong correlation. The least strong correlation has been found between time and GHG, which is a weak correlation. The findings also show how significantly the change in project conditions and decision-making process affect the relationship of TCEI, which helps construction contractors to be aware of the influence of their decisions on the project objectives.  

With a good understanding about the analytic process, the project team moved on to study building cases by collaborating with the Miami Dade School District for data collection and outreach. To achieve the objective, a simulation environment called Simulation of Environmental Impacts of Construction (SimulEICon) has been developed to quantitatively reveal the interdependency of TCEI. The research study analyzed three different phases of a building: design, construction, and use. During the building design and construction phases, the study could not confirm any statistical correlation between time, cost, and greenhouse gas emissions at the material-level; however, at the building-level, the study statistically confirmed trade-off relationships between construction time and each of construction cost and greenhouse gas emissions. Furthermore, the relationship between construction cost and greenhouse gas emissions exhibited a positive correlation. During the use phase, the positive correlation between construction costs and greenhouse gas emissions continued to exist regardless of the length of the analysis span. These results and the mathematical models developed under this project will enable the development of environmentally-conscious building designs while still satisfying other objectives such as time and cost. Furthermore, this project paves the way for further fundamental research in building design science and integrated project delivery systems.
